title: 114_hr6175
content:
Section 212(a)(3)(B)(i) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include aliens identified in the terrorist screening database, with an exception for those lawfully admitted for permanent residence. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to exempt lawful permanent residents from deportation if identified in the terrorist screening database. Additionally, waivers of inadmissibility grounds are provided for such aliens. Section 212(d)(3) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow for individual case-by-case basis consideration for granting nonimmigrant visas in the national security interests of the United States. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the discretion to grant nonimmigrant visas in the national security interests of the United States, with the requirement of unanimous concurrence from key officials. SEC. 4. UNAVAILABILITY OF CERTAIN IMMIGRATION BENEFITS TO ALIENS IDENTIFIED IN TERRORIST SCREENING DATABASE. (a) Amendment to asylum provision under the Immigration and Nationality Act to include new category (IX).
(b) Amendment to withholding of removal provision to include new inadmissibility and deportability criteria.
(c) Amendment to cancellation of removal provision for certain permanent residents regarding inadmissibility. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include new criteria for inadmissibility and deportability, specifically for certain nonpermanent residents. This amendment affects sections related to cancellation of removal. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include new criteria for inadmissibility and deportability for certain nonpermanent residents, affecting sections related to cancellation of removal. The Secretary of Homeland Security is prohibited from allowing an alien to depart voluntarily if they were previously found inadmissible or are inadmissible or deportable under specific sections. Additionally, adjustments are made to section 245 regarding the removal of certain items. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include new criteria for inadmissibility and deportability for certain nonpermanent residents. Section 245 is adjusted to remove specific items related to inadmissibility and deportability. Section 249 is also amended to change references from the Attorney General to the Secretary of Homeland Security. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include new criteria for inadmissibility and deportability for certain nonpermanent residents. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to revise regulations implementing the United Nations Convention Against Torture within 120 days of the enactment of the Act. The revised regulations exclude certain aliens from protection and make them ineligible for withholding or deferral of removal under immigration laws. They also allow for reopening and readjudication of past determinations, applying to acts and conditions regardless of when they occurred. SEC. 5. EXPEDITED REMOVAL OF ALIENS INADMISSIBLE OR DEPORTABLE ON SECURITY AND RELATED GROUNDS. Section 238 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow for the removal of aliens who are not permanent residents and are inadmissible or deportable on security or related grounds. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows for the removal of aliens who are inadmissible or deportable on security grounds, issuing orders of removal to those falling under specific sections. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows for the removal of aliens who are inadmissible or deportable on security grounds, issuing orders of removal to those falling under specific sections, such as section 212(a)(3)(B) and section 237(a)(4)(B). An alien described in this context is one who has not been granted a waiver under section 212(d)(3)(C) and was not lawfully admitted for permanent residence at the time proceedings commenced. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows for the removal of aliens who are inadmissible or deportable on security grounds. Proceedings under this subsection shall be expedited and in accordance with regulations set by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The alien must be given notice of charges and the opportunity for representation by counsel of their choice at no expense to the government. The alien must have the opportunity to be represented by counsel of their choice at no cost to the government, inspect evidence, ensure their identity is confirmed, maintain a record for judicial review, and have the final removal order adjudicated by a different person. The Secretary of Homeland Security must wait 14 days before executing any order to allow the alien to apply for judicial review. Adjudicated aliens are not eligible for discretionary relief from removal. The Act and its amendments will be effective upon enactment and will apply to all aliens in the terrorist screening database from that date onwards.
